or migrating existing software to a source delivery sas delivery model there's several real fundamental value
propositions of sas in general one is it allows the isv to sell more right sell more in two dimensions sell more
from a geographic standpoint where an isv in india can now actually sell a hosted erp
solution to a customer in latin america right companies like ramco for example right where they don't have to go set up
a footprint now in latin america to be able to cater to that market by working in the cloud and delivering your product over
the internet you actually can reach customers around the globe where you previously weren't able to
and also being able to sell to different market segments right so if you have traditionally had
complex enterprise software that required a very robust i.t staff and small to
medium businesses or even small to medium enterprises might not have had the skill sets required well sas takes all the
complexity out of that so it allows these isvs to sell to a bigger section of the market
dunks want to sell faster right if you look at the average sales cycle for enterprise software it's probably around
nine months or so if you look at the amount of time in that nine months that actually has to do with demonstrating the value of the
software itself is probably about a couple of weeks right so if you're able to instantly
spend up a demo environment and provide your customers with instant time to value for your application and you can shorten
the sales cycle from nine months to let's call in a month that's a good thing
any software company i've ever talked to or any company ever talked to said hey if there's a way for you to sell more and sell faster it's add a good thing
and you know it's somewhat self-evident but yes absolutely the next is improve the customer
experience right uh the distributed computing when we moved
from mainframe to distributed computing one thing happened which was increased diversity which was great
customers could choose from different providers to different suppliers which help drive down the cost of computing in
the market right but what it did is on the flip side of that actually increased complexity
right because now you have all these different components made by multiple multiple vendors you have to have people
to stitch it all together and the time to value was lengthened because it required everything to be
delivered and stitched together well with with the software as a service delivery model it's instant right so you improve the customer experience
customers don't have to do upgrades customers don't have to do security patches customers don't have to
manage the systems themselves it's simply consuming it as they use it and then finally
for an isv reducing the support and engineering expense prior to the internet and prior to the
cloud and prior to software as a service one of the biggest one of the biggest
cost centers for an isv would be where the money that they had to spend on sustaining engineering
in support of legacy applications right because once once a customer would typically do a deployment they're not going to touch it
if they don't have to right so you're now isvs had to support multiple versions of their products
on a near infinite number of configurations of hardware platforms with add the number of operating systems on
top of that and then add a virtualization layer on top of that it becomes this very complex very hairy
matrix of support dependencies that you have to maintain well if you deploy vsas again you build
your software for one platform the one that you control and therefore you can take the money that was
that would other isvs spend the sustaining engineering and move that into product innovation right now so why sas

and have that business view and what are the core services i need to have sit behind that and in many cases these aren't you know
you don't necessarily have to build these but you have to have a solution around them you could be using another sas provider for example
that's providing you a monitoring solution on top so it could be a composition of services your sas relies on another
sas for example so some best practices i want to make sure if you're thinking about building a
sas today then i'll make sure these are things we've learned from from our customers and the experience we've seen out in the
field the first is to think about separating that platform from the product right or the program itself the
application they are distinct things you want reusability you want to be evolved you want to evolve your
application over time so you're going to have a v1 and then you're going to get feedback it's not perfect never is and now it's a
service so it's not like a shipped product it's not like a v1 v2 thing it's a constantly evolving platform
which means you're going to want to decouple a lot of those core services from the application that allow you to
evolve that application quickly over time so really separating out the metering monitoring billing
analytics from the application itself so you can do a v1 v2 v3 real time very quickly move and evolve
obviously you know you can use this suite of services to support a fleet of sas applications you know don't limit yourself and think that
you're going to build just one sas app and even if you do just build one sas app you're going to have lots of versions over time so think of each
version as another application and you have to think about how do i support that how do i evolve that over time so
definitely an important component there in terms of decoupling um and of course the nice thing about doing
this kind of distributed model which really fits very closely with service oriented architecture
in general is the idea that you can tune and optimize individual components right so the the load that you're going
to take in your metering platform is different than the load you're going to take and your billing engine is different than the load you're going to
need for your analytics pieces it's different than the load for your authentication authorization each of those is going to need different
infrastructure types different types of throughput for network and cpu and memory making smaller components that you can
then tune effectively is an important step in your architecture i mean i think that it's doubly so when
you think about sas because the magnitude and scale is different um when you think about writing an app for one set of customers
that's that's fine you may have a thousand customers and they might have a thousand users well now it's a multiplier
right so a thousand users is one problem a thousand customers with a thousand users is a much bigger problem
so the scale can grow much faster than you imagine um it gets exponential very quickly so think about how to do this up
front is key um now oftentimes we get this question which is how do i how do i build my app like
what's the approach especially if you have something existing many customers i've worked with have an existing product they're like

i mean there's really three major approaches we're starting to see develop on top of aws and the first is the
probably the most obvious straightforward approach it's really about this isolated customer stack so each customer gets their own entire
stack of infrastructure it's kind of like application hosting as a service you know is the model and
it's a great way to get started and i'll talk a little bit more about that approach in just a minute but it's a great starting point for existing
software you don't have to do a lot of changes but you can get quickly onto the platform the next is kind of the end state what
about a pure sas solution where every resource is shared you have a pool of servers that servers
can can handle a request from any customer and any user of any customer right so it then has a much deeper
impact in terms of how that code understands dealing with individual customer requests how it routes
traffic inside the environment but it's a shared pool of resources probably the most cost efficient and cost effective model but
it adds a significant engineering challenge of thinking about how to handle requests from any customer for
any need in a common pool we'll talk about that a little more as well and then the middle the middle ground is

and improved our ec2 container service the idea of docker as a model for doing
containers or sub slicing your infrastructure has gained a lot of ground and certainly a lot of
support in the software industry of late it's a model that allows you to maybe optimize if you will the resource
consumption so you don't get the sprawl of lots of infrastructure in the isolated stacks
but you don't have to make as many changes maybe as building a pure sas model we'll talk about those in just a second
so the isolated customer stacks fairly straightforward i don't think i'm going to surprise anyone here but the
idea here you know you have your load balancer your auto scaling groups the entire application stack exists for every customer
and then you leverage our tagging uh infrastructure as a way to flow the the billing information through all
the way into your bill so you can tag all the resources inside that stack with a consistent tagging approach your
taxonomy and you know cost center equals customer one and then in your detailed billing report you can then look and say oh well here's

provisioning a whole new stack right cloud formation template associated with the entire stack that
installs the software adds maybe a user or two to your authentication database or a customer and then you have
a completely new customer stack where it's tagged again appropriately to that new customer
fairly straightforward model if you had an existing product and said how do i make it a sas you'd probably start here and this may

dedicated infrastructure okay well then they could have this particular approach whereas you might have another class of customer that is
happier with a shared pool of resources for maybe a lower price point right so you have that flexibility in
the platform so this is you know your your standard isolated stack approach the the shared model says hey customer
one and customer two come into the same endpoints um maybe there's some you know some nice domain um some uh
some uh you know special domain names for it make them feel better um from there it's their endpoint but really
it's a shared infrastructure they're flowing through um a common set of resources the web servers the app servers understand
request x that's coming through my platform is for customer y is for user z of customer y
and it knows exactly how to handle that that same server can handle a request from any customer uh you know any user of any customer um
the the benefit of this approach is that you know obviously much tightly more tightly aligned from a resources perspective to exactly your
consumption you're not going to have a partially used server that's sitting in an isolated customer stack you're going to have a much
greater density of much higher utilization of the services and it allows you to also build one code
base that you can then maintain you don't worry about as much differentiation between individual customer approaches the trick
with this one however is now when you think about how do i meter this i want to charge back to that customer you have to think about that metering
model of i need to then each of these individual servers or resources has to understand how to pass information on about how
much time was used so when a request comes in you may say well i processed a gigabyte of data
and it took me you know 20 minutes and 3 000 you know cpu cycles or 3 million probably more likely that
you know you have to meter that you have to capture that information along the way maybe real time maybe as a batch process
but that allows you to analyze the consumption of the platform so you have a more complex challenge in analyzing what's been done
but it's going to give you a higher resource density and resource utilization level
and then there's that uh third model which is the containerization approach now you've got individual docker
containers how many folks use docker today how many folks know what docker is
okay that's good and then the last question how many folks can spell docker
wow actually less than use it that's awesome um it's the beauty of google autocorrect is
amazing um so uh in this model uh you know customer one would come in and they would they
would route their traffic to the blue slices you know and customer two would come in and they would write their traffic to the orange slices the docker containers
the nice thing here is that you can get a fairly reasonable density of utilization those servers you get
fast deployment because containers spin up faster than virtual machines and then you can go ahead and track the
usage at the container level so when you add a new customer you know you'd go through the amazon ec2
container service and we've added some some nice features in our scheduler um some announcements this morning on that
to then have multiple container models and deployments you can then talk to that service for deploying the infrastructure and then
talk to that service about consumption as well in terms of what's being used you'd still might consider using uh some
custom metering but that service can give you at least some visibility into what's being deployed and where you're spending your your uh your cycles
in that environment so um now there's three different models and and actually there's lots of models
for how to build this and the reason why is because you really want to think about um how you optimize for cost and performance um in the platform
um and those are not orthogonal a lot of folks will say well if it's you know if it's really cost effective it's not necessarily fast
enough but if it's really performing it's really expensive i don't think that's necessarily true it's all about mapping the cost and
performance expectations of your customer to the architecture you choose so think about this example um
you might have an offering that has multiple different uh versions you might have a a silver
you know standard offering that is a best effort you know it puts messages into a queue to say hey i'll process this when i get to it
and there's a fixed pool processing those messages right that's perfectly fine but some customers
say that's not really fast enough for me well you could have another offering that's a gold you know offering that actually that has
always running high performance computing environments always available it costs more to run that so there's actually a higher price point for that
offering as well so you can actually tune your architecture and how you consume aws resources
to the customer need and their expectations around cost and performance so you want to think about that and
honestly when you go through an architecture you want to think about that architecture from multiple different customer
expectation sets right here's a new customer they're a small one i just picked them off off the internet
they never talked to me they just signed up for my service it's the best effort okay here's what the architecture would would look like to meet their
expectations versus this is my enterprise play these are my highest end customers who are you know
paying a premium to get the best possible version here's what their architecture looks like and you want to think about that not
just from an infrastructure perspective but how your software operates so you can see in that diagram you know
there's different maybe there's different cues for for processing uh work right there's a there's a best
effort queue that goes to a worker pool that is you know never going to change in size and then there's a high performance queue and your software understands how
to route that appropriately um you know the best effort cube might leverage spot for a much lower price point from a processing
perspective whereas the high performance queue will leverage an always-on fleet of ec2 instances that are doing that workload
so it's really about optimizing around what your customers want and what's going to fit best with that particular business model
and i think you know there's some optimizations to make architecturally so ideas of you know horizontal scalability being the model i think that everyone
gets that one that's a common cloud tenant but even the idea of smaller parallelizable resource units to light a greater
density so you instead of you know optimizing your code to run in the largest possible box
optimize it to be paralyzed in lots of smaller boxes so you get greater density so when you add a new machine you're not
worried about consuming the the whole box because you can consume more of it with just a small incremental change
and then leveraging the scalable services that you have no work to scale yourself so something like
dynamodb where you're not worried about provisioning additional infrastructure you just pass an api call to say i need more
throughput reads and writes and that simplifies your life in a lot of these scenarios when you think about how to scale and
grow from a cost and performance perspective the other thing to think about is multi-multi-tenancy i made the example
before you know now it's not when you're building your software you're not building it for one customer and they're a user base you're building
it for all your customers and all their users so it's really a multiple customers with multiple users so it's a multiplying factor and it's a
significant one when it comes to how you design your software so an example might be your in your data model where you're
when you wrote your software the first time you said well i got a database and it's a single customer database so my schema is such that i just look up
all the orders for that customer well turns out when you've got a shared data scheme and now you have to have a
customer column on top so now i want to look at the orders but not all the orders only the orders for that customer and their user base
so you got to think about how how does your data schema change how do you store and access data differently um so there
are some different thinkings when you sort of expand beyond the single customer deployment and go into a multi-customer
multi-user model um i think i talked about this in the last slide a little bit the idea of providing tiers for request
prioritization another thing to think about tiers of performance and and um response time um and then of course you know i think
it's kind of makes sense you monitor everything closely and distribute it um efficiently across the platform as best as you can but that's going to come
down to how you evolve and grow your your software over time the other thing that's important to think about
especially when you're running a sas is the life cycle of your data i've talked to many customers over the
years who will say oh you know it's great you know we built the platform we got a data
model it's where we're storing it we're putting everything in the database um and then the question comes well how how long does it stay in the database
like well it stays in the database forever i mean you know so that's where the software works you just put in the database well when you're running it
for them now you've got to think about how long do i really want to keep that data is that data relevant after six months a year three years seven
years and and is that really cost effective too um i'll use an amazon example to highlight this point
when you go to look at your order history on amazon the last year or so is going to be kept in a low low
latency fast access data store because you're going to pull that up when you want it you want it right now it's a pretty common scenario to look at your orders
right however if you go back to your orders from seven years ago that doesn't need to be in a database
how commonly do you go to that how fast do you expect that really to perform on your behalf um so in actual fact that can go to a
flat file on s3 to pull that out right it's a completely different data storage model because the expectations
of performance and the likelihood of it being used are different so knowing the life cycle of your data and how it evolves over
time is a really important one because that actually will have a pretty significant impact in your overall data storage and compute
costs um storing data and paying for you know a highly performant database
um for everything doesn't necessarily make sense if you're going to run it all for them you know for in perpetuity so thinking about that from a design
perspective is an important one and then the last one and i'll harp on that i could harp on this all day long
this could be a whole talk by itself um is really collect everything and learn from it um the most important
thing to realize is you can't improve something if you can't measure it right if you don't have data that you're looking at you can't you don't know if
your change made an impact right so you really do have to collect across the board um so obviously you know closely and
monitoring infrastructure makes you know obvious sense you want to make sure everything's running smoothly
you want to collect your metrics reliably and you want to store them durably the the idea here is hey you know rotate
your logs drop them at s3 keep them for you know keep them forever because who knows when you want to go back and analyze the last five years of
usage and understand what your customers were doing back then versus now and how that's evolved over
time um if you don't have them you can't look at them and there's lots obviously lots of storage models that can make this cost
effective know your customers so one thing that this is a story that's interesting is we
had a customer who was building a sas offering and they had been been storing a whole bunch of data and
building search on top of it well one of the challenges came later on when search got really expensive to run
it's very complex to build the indexing servers and there was lots of data storage it was a whole nother data set really they discovered they
didn't have the information in their application to analyze who was calling search and what they were searching
they didn't really have the data about the customers and what their activity was so the idea of instrumenting your code all the way through so not just the not
just the calls the front end but the calls to the app tier and the database and the other ancillary services all
contain a you know a customer identifier you know we're not talking a social security number talking obfuscated
identifier you can use to identify unique users allows you to know who they are and what they're doing it
allows you to analyze what's happening and that's not necessarily a common design principle in a lot of software
but analyzing that who who's doing it through the entire platform gives you the ability to know your customers and what they're really doing
and then evolve based on that and that's actually probably the most interesting part about how sas changes the traditional software
development model is that now you actually have real data about what customers did how they used it when they used it what
they did with it how long it took them you know how often they use it things that you may never have had before
when you think about shipping bits you know you never necessarily have the visibility into what they're doing and we're not talking about you know nsa
spying we're talking about basic you know monitoring of your platform and how it's consumed you know that's really what what you can
do now and have a visibility into it allows you to evolve based on it um you can change your software you can create differentiated
offerings based on consumption models you can really monetize the data you collect in the sense that you can evolve
the platform and make it more efficient because it's like you know you know the common scenarios you know what customers are really trying to do
